title: What is the difference between 'Mother's Maiden Name' and 'Maiden Name'? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Maiden name” is the surname you were given at birth. “Mother's maiden name” is the surname your mother had at birth. An example. My surname at birth, also called my maiden name, was Kaufman, because my father's surname was Kaufman. My mother's surname at birth, also called my mother's maiden name, was Weinroth. She took my father's surname when she married him. I subsequently married a man with the surname Shattuck and took his surname. We divorced, and my divorce decree allowed me to return to using my maiden name, so my name today and my maiden name are the same — Kaufman. My mother's maiden name was Weinroth. She took my father's surname of Kaufman when she married him. Many years later, he died, and my mother eventually married a man with the surname Bamberger. She used his surname socially, but kept my father's name professionally.

Originally a maiden is a young, single (and innocent) female. She was a “maid” - read virgin. Her maiden name is her family (surname/last name, call it what you will) as it was when she was a maiden. When she got married she took on her husbands family name. This is her married name. Things change. These days many women stick with their maiden name throughout their life regardless of marital status. But if you are filling out a form which asks for ‘maiden name’ - they want your maiden name. If the forms asks for ‘mother’s maiden name’ then they want your mothers maiden name.
